thread.title: Terrifying video of small girl being pulled alive from Syrian rubble shines light on another deadly Damascus day
thread.title_full: Terrifying video of small girl being pulled alive from Syrian rubble shines light on another deadly Damascus day

title: Terrifying video of small girl being pulled alive from Syrian rubble shines light on another deadly Damascus day
text:
Terrifying video of small girl being pulled alive from Syrian rubble shines light on another deadly Damascus day Last updated 15:10, February 21 2017 
GRAPHIC CONTENT: Rescuers miraculously rescue a young girl alive from under the rubble of a building struck by an airstrike in Damascus. 
GRAPHIC CONTENT: Video of a young girl being pulled from the rubble of a building hit by an airstrike has shone the light on what has been a deadly day in the Syrian capital. 
Airstrikes left at least seven people dead on Tuesday morning (NZT) as activists reported a third straight day of escalations by pro-government forces against opposition-held areas inside and around the capital. 
The Syrian Civil Defense first responders, also known as the White Helmets, released the video. SUPPLIED 
Volunteers rescued a girl, bottom left, from under the rubble of a collapsed building in the Tishreen neighbourhood of Damascus. 
It showed its volunteers trying to rescue a girl from under the rubble of a collapsed building after an airstrike on the Tishreen neighbourhood. 
READ MORE: 
The rescuers said the words 'God is great, God is great' as the girl, who the Daily Mail reported was called Aya, was taken to safety. SUPPLIED 
The girl is pulled from the rubble alive. 
The extent of her injuries were unclear. 
Jets believed to belong to the Russian or Syrian Air Forces pounded the Barzeh and Qaboun neighbourhoods in the northeast corner of the capital, leveling several buildings, and also wounded at least 12 people, the activist-run Barzeh Media Center and Britain-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported. 
The side-by-side Barzeh, Qaboun, and Tishreen neighborhoods form one of the last two footholds of the Syrian opposition inside the Damascus city limits. 
The two neighbourhoods connect to a vast, opposition-held district in the suburbs of the capital through a network of smuggling tunnels, according to Syria researcher Aron Lund, in a report for the US-based Century Foundation policy institute. Ad Feedback 
Pro-government forces have so far failed to collapse rebel defenses inside the Eastern Ghouta district, despite besieging them there since 2013. 
Also on Monday (Tuesday NZT), the Russian military reported the deaths of four of its servicemen when they their vehicle was struck by a roadside in the centre of the country last Thursday. 
The loss raised the total Russian combat casualties so far in Syria's war to 27. 
The four died when they were travelling as part of a Syrian military convoy to the central city of Homs on Thursday from the Tiyas air base, which is close to the ancient town of Palmyra held by the Islamic State group. 
The Russian Defense Ministry said the bomb was detonated by remote control. Two other servicemen were wounded in the blast. 
Palmyra, about 60 kilometres away, is one of the focal points of the battle against the extremist group. 
No group has claimed responsibility for the attack, but blame is likely to fall on IS. - AP
